sn45.1:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
sn45.1:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
sn45.1:2.1: “Mendicants, ignorance precedes the attainment of unskillful qualities, with lack of conscience and prudence following along.
sn45.1:2.2: An ignoramus, sunk in ignorance, gives rise to wrong view.
sn45.1:2.3: Wrong view gives rise to wrong thought.
sn45.1:2.4: Wrong thought gives rise to wrong speech.
sn45.1:2.5: Wrong speech gives rise to wrong action.
sn45.1:2.6: Wrong action gives rise to wrong livelihood.
sn45.1:2.7: Wrong livelihood gives rise to wrong effort.
sn45.1:2.8: Wrong effort gives rise to wrong mindfulness.
sn45.1:2.9: Wrong mindfulness gives rise to wrong immersion.
sn45.1:3.1: Knowledge precedes the attainment of skillful qualities, with conscience and prudence following along.
sn45.1:3.2: A sage, firm in knowledge, gives rise to right view.
sn45.1:3.3: Right view gives rise to right thought.
sn45.1:3.4: Right thought gives rise to right speech.
sn45.1:3.5: Right speech gives rise to right action.
sn45.1:3.6: Right action gives rise to right livelihood.
sn45.1:3.7: Right livelihood gives rise to right effort.
sn45.1:3.8: Right effort gives rise to right mindfulness.
sn45.1:3.9: Right mindfulness gives rise to right immersion.”
